III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical Assistance was provided to the facility to make sure that report dates
are consistent with the rule expectations. It was found there was multiple reports
were being completed due to increased court hearings making it confusing to
follow for report date requirements. The reminder was provided for youth that are
in short term/ detention side of the license needs to have a preliminary brief plan
report completed within 7 days of admission. Then a full resident report should be
completed 30 days after admission date and a written report every 15 days after
the full resident report. These timeframes/dates should be clear on the reports so
there is clarity of rule compliance with dates of reports. For treatment serviced
youth, an initial report needs to be completed within 30 days of admission and an
updated report should be completed at least once every 3 months after
completing the initial report. Timeframes should be documented on the reports
should be clear to make sure reports are following the rules.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
3

Maltreatment in Care
There was 1 substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. This was within Special Investigation 2023C0000784SI dated 11/30/2023
which found the facility in non-compliance of a staff member not following the
relationship policy and confidentiality policy. A Corrective Action Plan dated
11/15/2023 was approved that included the staff member involved being terminated
from employment, staff are now not being allowed to be in youth’s circle of support
post discharge, increased refresher trainings on both policies, and increased check
in’s with youth about staff boundaries.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
Special Investigation 2023C0000784SI with a CAP approval date of 11/15/2023
was a result of a violation for staff not following the facility’s relationship policy with
youth and privacy and confidential policy. The facility terminated the employee that
was involved within the situation, staff are now not being allowed to be in youth’s
circle of support post discharge, increased refresher trainings on both policies, and
increased check in’s with youth about staff boundaries. This CAP was reviewed
quarterly, and all action steps were completed timely.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001421 with a CAP approval date of 06/17/2024
was a result of a violation of staff not following the internal behavioral management
policy and pushed a youth. The facility gave the staff member involved a
disciplinary letter, had to complete a one-on-one refresher training on behavior
management, and for the next six months video footage of this staff shifts will be
reviewed by administration. The facility also completed a refresher training with all
staff on behavior management. The facility is currently complying with the CAP
action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted
concerns.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001458 with a CAP approval date of 07/22/2024
was a result of a violation of staff member not completing a restraint per training.
The staff member involved completed a Handle with Care refresher training and all
other staff will continue to complete their annual training of the restraint model. The
facility will review random video footage of restraints that completed to ensure
restraints are being completed per model standard. The facility is currently
complying with the CAP action steps, and DCWL continues to monitor CAP
compliance with no noted concerns.

Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviews were conducted during the inspection and no issues or concerns
were raised. Staff reported they feel well supported by their direct supervisor and
administration team. They reported over the past years there has been an increase
in pay which has resulted in staff staying longer and more qualified staff coming to
work at the facility. When staff were asked if there was anything they wanted to
change at the facility, staff responded in wanting to work towards giving the youth
more choices such as choosing what sport they want to play or what activity they
want to do on the pod. This was shared with administration.
Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection. The youth reported they
feel safe at the facility and are treated well by staff. The youth reported they feel
their grievances have all been taken seriously and have been addressed by
administration. They reported staff use verbal de-escalation skills more than going
hands on with a youth and noted staff only goes hands on when there is a safety
issue. One youth reported concerns that the kitchen staff do not always take the
diet restrictions seriously and have to be reminded. The youth reported that he is
supposed to eat only soft foods and has been provided some items that are harder
to eat, which he then has to ask for new food which is provided to him. This
feedback was shared with administration.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on August 8, 2024.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
